questions.question: What are examples of cardinal and intercardinal/quadrantal points?
questions.answer: Cardinal: North, South, East, West. Intercardinal: Northeast, Southeast, Southwest, Northwest.

questions.question: The __________ North Pole is  used as reference for True direction?
The North-seeking end of a magnetic compass is often coloured __________.
VFR Aeronautical charts are referenced to __________ North.
IFR Aeronautical charts are referenced to __________ North.
What is the name of the value added or subtracted to convert between °T and °M?
What is the definition of magnetic variation.
questions.answer: The angular difference between True and Magnetic North at a given location.

questions.question: Magnetic variation is (the same/different) at different locations. It (does/does not) change over time.
What is the definition of an isogonal?
questions.answer: Lines joining places of the same magnetic variation.

questions.question: Where can you find the annual change in magnetic variation?
questions.answer: Printed in the legend of all aeronautical charts.

questions.question: To convert True headings to Magnetic, (add/subtract) easterly variation.
To convert True headings to Magnetic, (add/subtract) westerly variation.
To convert Magnetic headings to True, (add/subtract) easterly variation.
To convert Magnetic headings to True, (add/subtract) westerly variation.
What value is commonly used in New Zealand as a rough average variation?
Where can you find accurate variation values?
When measuring variation for a track crossing multiple isogonals, which value should you use?
questions.answer: The variation for the main part of the track.
